course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Computational Energy Materials and Electronic Structure Simulations
course.description: This course will introduce atomistic computational methods to model, understand, and predict the properties and behavior of real materials including solids, liquids, and nanostructures. Their applications to sustainable energy will be discussed. Specific topics include: density-functional theory (DFT), Kohn-Sham equations, local and semi-local density approximations and hybrid functionals, basis sets, pseudopotentials; Hartree-Fock method; ab initio molecular dynamics with interatomic interactions derived on the ﬂy from DFT, Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics; Monte-Carlo sampling; computational spectroscopy from ﬁrst principles, IR and Raman. Students will learn how to use free open-source packages to do materials simulations on a Linux computer cluster. Students should have basic knowledge of quantum mechanics. The instructor's approval is required for taking this course.

reviews.author: wilwin
reviews.comment_content: Good content, the material also includes the current state of research. Maybe need to include more applications.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great teaching skill, his explanation is very detailed. I can understand clearly, and he is always available for question after the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good grading for the middle term exam, the distribution is alright and fair. The grade for the HW is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload: Too much workload, especially for the last homework. Installing the Qbox package really takes too much time. More emphasize on debugging skill. Prefers more problem set kind of homeworks.
